citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
On a shelf in the food storage area containing medications for covered animals, there were medications that were not
adequately labeled and/or were out of date. There was a bottle of gabapentin that ex-pired 01/06/2025. There was also a
bag of white pills broken into pieces labelled as Metronidazole with no date of expiration on the container. Medical
supplies that are not properly labeled and/or not properly stored, could deteriorate, become contaminated, or be misused,
possibly resulting in harm to the health and well-being of the animals. Medicines used to prevent or treat disease must be
properly stored, labeled, and not expired in order for them to appropriately and effectively prevent, control, and/or treat
diseases.
Correct by: 03/07/2025

There were several exposed sharp wire points in the chain link fence wall of the bobcat enclosure above the water bucket.
Sharp points and edges are a potential risk to the health and welfare of the animals. Enclosures must be maintained in
good repair and protect the animals from injury.
Correct by: 03/07/2025

There was a bottle of cleaning solution stored on a shelf above the bird food preparation area. Spillage of toxic
substances in food preparation areas represents a potential risk to the health and welfare of the animals. Substances,
such as cleaning supplies, that are harmful to the birds, but required for normal husbandry practices, must not be in food
storage and preparation areas. These substances may be stored in cabinets in the animal areas, provided they are stored
in properly labeled containers that are adequately secured to prevent potential harm to the birds. This was corrected at
the time of inspection by moving the cleaning supplies to a cabinet.
Correct by: 03/6/2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Facility Representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
On a shelf in the food storage area containing medications for covered animals, there were medications that were not 
adequately labeled and/or were out of date. There was a bottle of gabapentin that ex-pired 01/06/2025. There was also a 
bag of white pills broken into pieces labelled as Metronidazole with no date of expiration on the container. Medical 
supplies that are not properly labeled and/or not properly stored, could deteriorate, become contaminated, or be misused, 
possibly resulting in harm to the health and well-being of the animals. Medicines used to prevent or treat disease must be 
properly stored, labeled, and not expired in order for them to appropriately and effectively prevent, control, and/or treat 
diseases. 
Correct by: 03/07/2025 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
There were several exposed sharp wire points in the chain link fence wall of the bobcat enclosure above the water bucket. 
Sharp points and edges are a potential risk to the health and welfare of the animals. Enclosures must be maintained in 
good repair and protect the animals from injury.  
Correct by: 03/07/2025 
3.150(e) 
   
Facilities, general. 
There was a bottle of cleaning solution stored on a shelf above the bird food preparation area. Spillage of toxic 
substances in food preparation areas represents a potential risk to the health and welfare of the animals. Substances, 
such as cleaning supplies, that are harmful to the birds, but required for normal husbandry practices, must not be in food 
storage and preparation areas. These substances may be stored in cabinets in the animal areas, provided they are stored 
in properly labeled containers that are adequately secured to prevent potential harm to the birds. This was corrected at 
the time of inspection by moving the cleaning supplies to a cabinet.  
Correct by: 03/6/2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Facility Representative.
